newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Gunmen kill Sunni Moslems in Pakistani city.
newsitem.headline: Gunmen kill Sunni Moslems in Pakistani city.

text.p: Gunmen on a motorcycle shot dead two Sunni Moslems and wounded one in Lahore on Wednesday in what police said appeared to be a sectarian attack.
They said two gunmen fired on Rashid Ahmed, owner of a stationery shop, and his salesman Nizam Din when they were opening the store in the morning. They died at the scene.
A third salesman was critically wounded.
Ahmed was a well-known supporter of the militant Sunni Sipah-i-Sahaba Pakistan (SSP) group, and a month ago his brother was killed in Lahore.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the shooting, but it appeared to be the latest in a series of attacks for which rival militant groups of the majority Sunni and the minority Shi'ite sects blame each other.
On Tuesday, gunmen killed Haji Mohammad Yousaf, a SSP activist in Jhang town in the central province of Punjab.

Sectarian violence is rife in Punjab, where Sunni and Shi'ite factions are engaged in a feud that officials say has killed more than 100 people this year, including religious scholars, lawyers and doctors.
Sunni-Shi'ite disputes over Islamic beliefs have often turned violent in Pakistan. Such disputes cost at least 170 lives last year.
Shi'ites form about 15 percent of Pakistan's mainly Sunni population of more than 135 million people but are the majority in nearby Iran.
